author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Atari, Video Game Pioneer, Plans to Open 8 Hotels to ‘Eat, Sleep and Play’
description: “Our hope is that you come in and never want to leave because there’s a lot of interaction,” said an executive behind the project.
content: Atari, the brand known for pioneering video games like Pong, Asteroids and RollerCoaster Tycoon, is taking its business in a new direction: hotels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: These Images Show the Sun’s Surface in Greater Detail Than Ever Before
description: A new telescope in Hawaii takes aim at our nearest star and its mysteries.
content: On Wednesday, astronomers released what they said were the most detailed images ever taken of the surface of our sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Hooking the Reader Right From the Start: The Times Trilobites Column
description: Four techniques for writing engaging informational pieces, no matter what your topic is.
content: Our new Mentor Text series spotlights writing from The Times that students can learn from and emulate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Is Trump Bibi’s Chump?
description: The president needs to demand a commitment so he doesn’t get played.
content: TEL AVIV — Given the timing of the release on Tuesday of President Trump’s Middle East peace plan, I have to begin by asking: Is this plan about two states for two peoples or is it about one diversion for two dirty leaders?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathan Thrall
title: Trump’s Middle East Peace Plan Exposes the Ugly Truth
description: This isn’t a break with the status quo. It’s the natural culmination of decades of American policy.
content: On Tuesday, President Trump released his long-gestating plan for Middle East peace, the so-called “deal of the century.” It calls for a Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza; for Jerusalem, including its Old City, to be the undivided capital of Israel; and for Israel to annex all settlements, as well as the Jordan Valley — which makes up nearly a fourth of the West Bank, including its eastern border with Jordan — creating a discontiguous Palestinian archipelago state, surrounded by a sea of Israeli territory. Mr. Trump announced that the United States will recognize Israeli sovereignty over all the territory the plan assigns to Israel, and shortly after, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel pledged to annex all settlements and the Jordan Valley beginning on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Shain, Shola Lawal and Brad Plumer
title: One Thing You Can Do: Make Smart Donations
description: Also this week, African climate activists and a popular Berkeley class
content: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Boeing Expects 737 Max Costs Will Surpass $18 Billion
description: The grounding of the 737 Max jet continues to drag on the company’s results.
content: Boeing said on Wednesday that the costs associated with the grounding of the 737 Max were likely to surpass $18 billion, a significant increase over earlier forecasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Tara Koch
title: How to Ski European Pistes for Less
description: The European Alps are home to hundreds of resorts, many with a budget-friendly price tag.
content: Skiing in Europe can cost a pretty penny, especially if you stay at marquee resorts. Happily, the Alps are home to hundreds of ski-centric accommodations, many with budget-friendly price tags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor, Mariel Padilla and Sandra E. Garcia
title: Police Officer Charged With Murder in Killing of Handcuffed Suspect in Maryland
description: Michael Owen, a Prince George’s County police corporal, shot William H. Green seven times while he was handcuffed in a patrol car, the authorities said.
content: A police corporal in Maryland was charged with second-degree murder on Tuesday in the fatal shooting of a suspect who had been handcuffed in the front passenger seat of his patrol car the previous night, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Impeachment Enters Volatile New Phase as Senators Get to Ask Their Questions
description: Under impeachment’s arcane rules, senators will submit written queries to be read aloud by the chief justice. Leaders from both parties have strategized for days about what to ask.
content: WASHINGTON — After six days of carefully choreographed oral arguments, President Trump’s impeachment trial is about to enter a volatile phase as senators are allowed to ask whatever they want of House prosecutors and White House lawyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: There’s a Coyote in Central Park. Don’t Panic.
description: Several sightings could mean more than one animal, but an expert says that "co-existing with coyotes is pretty easy."
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Ally Held Event Handing Out Cash in a Black Community
description: The group that hosted the event last month in Cleveland is run by a prominent black ally of the president, and it promoted Trump administration policies while doling out cash prizes.
content: WASHINGTON — A nonprofit organization run by one of President Trump’s most prominent African-American allies recently held an event in a black community where it promoted Trump administration policies like criminal justice reform while doling out cash prizes to participants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Judith Levitt
title: Impeachment, Wuhan, Jessica Simpson: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Facebook’s Revenue Rises Again, but More Slowly Than Ever
description: The social network’s business has remained robust, though its sales growth slowed to 25 percent in the fourth quarter.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Even as Facebook has grappled with one corporate embarrassment after another, it has remained a business powerhouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh and Katie Thomas
title: Researchers Are Racing to Make a Coronavirus Vaccine. Will It Help?
description: New technology and better coordination have sped up development. But a coronavirus vaccine is still months — and most likely years — away.
content: In the early days of January, as cases of a strange, pneumonia-like illness were reported in China, researchers at the National Institutes of Health in Maryland readied themselves to hunt for a vaccine to prevent the new disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Mike Pompeo’s NPR Interview Left a Lot to Be Considered, Seth Meyers Says
description: Meyers advised Pompeo to “maybe don’t go on a show called ‘All Things Considered’” if he didn’t want to be asked questions about “all things.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Cooper
title: Bryn Terfel, Injured Opera Star, Leaves the Met’s New ‘Dutchman’
description: The bass-baritone’s planned return to the company, after eight years, was canceled because of an ankle fracture.
content: In Wagner’s “Der Fliegende Holländer,” a bewitched sea captain is allowed to leave his ship only once every seven years, to try to break the spell that has condemned him to roam the oceans for eternity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: 7 Reasons Recycling Isn’t Working in New York City
description: New York recycles only about a fifth of its trash, lagging behind other major cities and slowing its quest to reduce waste.
content: If you are a New Yorker and sort your recycling at home, as city law mandates, you probably wonder, as you rinse bottles and stack junk mail and scrub yogurt containers: Does all this effort make a difference?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: The One About Iowa, Black Voters and Barack Obama
description: Some Democratic presidential candidates have viewed an Obama-like Iowa victory as the key to helping them with black voters in other states. But the Obama campaign did a lot more than just win Iowa.
content: DES MOINES — It has become political lore, repeated on cable airwaves and by Democratic campaign consultants, even presidential candidates. In 2008, as the story goes, black voters were uncertain about Barack Obama’s presidential candidacy until he won the Iowa caucuses, after which they rallied around him over the onetime front-runner, Hillary Clinton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan and Katie Glueck
title: Biden Plans a Counterattack at Trump as Impeachment Tensions Rise
description: Joe Biden will deliver a speech on Thursday forcefully rebuking the president, whose allies in Congress have increasingly set their sights on the former vice president.
content: DES MOINES — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., after coming under assault at the impeachment trial, plans on Thursday to offer a forceful rebuke of President Trump that will double as a closing message ahead of the Iowa caucuses on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Michael D. Shear
title: Republicans Move to Block Impeachment Witnesses, Driving Toward Acquittal
description: Efforts to bring wavering Republicans into line appeared to be working as President Trump’s lawyers argued that anything a president did to win re-election was “in the public interest.”
content: WASHINGTON — The White House and Senate Republicans worked aggressively on Wednesday to discount damaging revelations from John R. Bolton and line up the votes to block new witnesses from testifying in President Trump’s impeachment trial, in a push to bring the proceeding to a swift close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Kobe Bryant’s ‘Mamba Army’ Fans Were as Relentless as He Was
description: Bryant’s fans channeled his tenacious persona to defend him against criticisms, big and small, and to proclaim his superiority over all other superstars.
content: The mention of Kobe Bryant could instantly start a fight, whether in a bar with friends or a in far-flung corner of the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Shain, Shola Lawal and Brad Plumer
title: One Thing You Can Do: Make Smart Donations

title: Inside a 1901 Amsterdam Townhouse
description: This six-bedroom triplex in the leafy Weesperzijde neighborhood of Amsterdam is on the market for $1.9 million.
content: This six-bedroom triplex in the leafy Weesperzijde neighborhood of Amsterdam is on the market for $1.9 million.

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: As Tesla Earnings Arrive, Bulls and Bears Continue to Spar
description: Faith in Elon Musk’s company has driven its stock to new heights. But detractors think their skepticism will be vindicated in the end.
content: Tesla’s stock price has soared for months, leaving investors and analysts deeply divided over a single question: Is Tesla a bubble?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Mannering
title: You Remember Jessica Simpson, Right? Wrong
description: The singer and fashion mogul is ready to talk about sexual abuse, addiction, dating John Mayer and everything else.
content: HIDDEN HILLS, Calif. — On a top shelf of a built-in bookcase in a dark and donnish study of a home here sit several copies — some first editions — of a story about chasing stardom. It’s also a story about love versus obsession. Or maybe, most simply, it’s a rags-to-riches tale about a country kid who becomes famous in the big city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: These Images Show the Sun’s Surface in Greater Detail Than Ever Before
description: A new telescope in Hawaii takes aim at our nearest star and its mysteries.
content: On Wednesday, astronomers released what they said were the most detailed images ever taken of the surface of our sun.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Four techniques for writing engaging informational pieces, no matter what your topic is.
content: Our new Mentor Text series spotlights writing from The Times that students can learn from and emulate.

author: By Nicole Daniels and Michael Gonchar
title: Do You Think the World Is Getting Closer to Securing the Promise of ‘Never Again’?
description: In the years following the Holocaust, the phrase has come to represent a universal goal to prevent future genocides. Are we moving in the right direction?
content: Note to Teachers: The article linked below contains photographs from the Holocaust and includes images of violence and murder. Please preview before sharing with students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Whipping Up Chocolate Mousse Is Stressful. A Blender Makes It Easy.
description: A chocolate mousse so fast and unfussy — but still airy and creamy — that it might become your go-to dessert.
content: I was impressed by Danou, a family friend who lived next door to me in rural France, not just because she was significantly older (retired) and smoked Gauloises (one pack a day) and had two dogs (two!), but because her go-to dessert was chocolate mousse. She had a life outside the kitchen, but so much of the time I spent with her was on the weekends, hanging around her house as she got ready for Sunday lunch, helping her make that mousse. It was a process, the same each time, and my responsibilities were fairly small. I cracked and separated the eggs and checked the bowls for egg shell. I broke the chocolate along segment lines and checked the bowl for foil bits. I set a pot of water on to boil, to melt the chocolate. Then I climbed onto the counter to get the Bowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Steiner
title: For Some Resorts, Multi-Mountain Passes Mean Crowded Slopes and Longer Lift Lines
description: The popularity of IKON and Epic passes have ski resorts cutting off weekend sales at the windows and warning crowds on social media to stay home.
content: Last month, the Crystal Mountain Resort announced it would no longer sell ski-lift tickets at its windows on weekends, a startling move in an industry that has historically sought volume and the high margin returns from single-day lift ticket sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: E.U. Recommends Limiting, but Not Banning, Huawei in 5G Rollout
description: The bloc’s experts suggested members limit and monitor the involvement of “high-risk” vendors as they invest in next-generation mobile communications infrastructure.
content: The European Union told its members on Wednesday that they should limit so-called high-risk 5G vendors, a category that includes the Chinese tech giant Huawei, but stopped short of recommending a ban on the firm, despite a lengthy and aggressive campaign by the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Wuhan, Middle East peace deal, impeachment: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Businesses like Starbucks, Ikea, Ford and Toyota are shutting down locations in China, and Apple is rerouting supply chains as the number of people infected by a mysterious flulike virus passes 6,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: How Much Are We Paying for Our Subscription Services? A Lot
description: The dollars are adding up fast. So here are some tips for pruning the subscriptions you no longer use.
content: Online subscriptions sure sound cheap, but what do a few bucks a month to watch TV shows, store photos online and stream music add up to?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Richarz
title: A Few Etiquette Tips for Getting Around Japan
description: Heading to Tokyo for the 2020 Summer Olympics? Here are some lesser-known tips on avoiding faux pas and other cultural missteps while there.
content: Japanese society, known for its polite orderliness, is heavily dependent on unspoken understandings and behavior aimed at maintaining the “wa” — the idea of social harmony. With Tokyo bracing for an influx of tourists for the 2020 Summer Olympics, here are some lesser-known tips for first-timers on avoiding faux pas and other cultural missteps while in Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What to See Right Now in New York Art Galleries
description: Katherine Bernhardt’s E.T. paintings; Michael Rakowitz’s reconstructions of antiquities; and Juanita McNeely’s contorted female figures.
content: People of all ages fell for the cute gnome-like alien at the center of Steven Spielberg’s 1982 movie “E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial.” But some fell extra hard; Katherine Bernhardt, who turned 7 the year the movie premiered, was smitten enough to paint portraits of E.T. in art school. In her latest show, “Done with Xanax,” she returns to him, pushing her distinctive fusion of Pop Art, Color Field and graffiti toward a more vulnerable, narrative expression and more complex painting process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: Goldman Sachs Is Remaking Itself (Again)
description: After a tough few years, the bank is hoping its first “investor day” on Wednesday will help it return to Wall Street favor.
content: Goldman Sachs is going to do something unusual this week: talk openly with investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Whipping Up Chocolate Mousse Is Stressful. A Blender Makes It Easy.
description: A chocolate mousse so fast and unfussy — but still airy and creamy — that it might become your go-to dessert.
content: I was impressed by Danou, a family friend who lived next door to me in rural France, not just because she was significantly older (retired) and smoked Gauloises (one pack a day) and had two dogs (two!), but because her go-to dessert was chocolate mousse. She had a life outside the kitchen, but so much of the time I spent with her was on the weekends, hanging around her house as she got ready for Sunday lunch, helping her make that mousse. It was a process, the same each time, and my responsibilities were fairly small. I cracked and separated the eggs and checked the bowls for egg shell. I broke the chocolate along segment lines and checked the bowl for foil bits. I set a pot of water on to boil, to melt the chocolate. Then I climbed onto the counter to get the Bowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Micah Goodman
title: The Three Crucial Flaws in Trump’s ‘Peace Vision’
description: His “ultimate deal” is still worth considering.
content: President Trump’s “Ultimate Deal” for Israeli-Palestinian peace isn’t ultimate, and it isn’t quite a deal. Released on Tuesday, the plan — or “Peace Vision,” as it’s called in its official document — has three flaws. None are fatal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: indomitable
description: This word has appeared in 82 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: House Democrats to Unveil $760 Billion Infrastructure Plan
description: The framework will outline investment over the next five years and provide a foundation for legislation that is currently being drafted or debated in House committees.
content: WASHINGTON — House Democrats on Wednesday plan to unveil a five-year, $760 billion framework for rebuilding the nation’s highways, airports and other infrastructure, laying out an election-year package with little chance of enactment after bipartisan talks with the White House on the issue failed to gain traction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Talk of Milk Industry Merger Draws Justice Dept. Scrutiny
description: Antitrust officials have been investigating a potential merger of the struggling milk giant Dean Foods with Dairy Farmers of America, a marketing cooperative.
content: When the struggling milk giant Dean Foods filed for bankruptcy protection in November, it also announced a possible path forward — a takeover by Dairy Farmers of America, a marketing cooperative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: E.U. Recommends Limiting, but Not Banning, Huawei in 5G Rollout
description: The bloc’s experts suggested members limit and monitor the involvement of “high-risk” vendors as they invest in next-generation mobile communications infrastructure.
content: The European Union told its members on Wednesday that they should limit so-called high-risk 5G vendors, a category that includes the Chinese tech giant Huawei, but stopped short of recommending a ban on the firm, despite a lengthy and aggressive campaign by the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Dominic Thiem Beats Rafael Nadal in Australian Open Quarterfinal
description: Thiem won in a thrilling four sets and will face Alexander Zverev in one semifinal. Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic are in the other.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — There will be a new-generation men’s semifinal at the Australian Open when Dominic Thiem faces Alexander Zverev for a chance to take on one of the sport’s Big Three for a title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Ehikhamenor
title: Give Us Back What Our Ancestors Made
description: Africans shouldn’t have to travel to Western museums to see the artworks looted from their continent.
content: LAGOS, Nigeria — There is an axiom of my elders: The earthworm says it used to own a lot of gold jewelry, but now that it burrows the earth and covers itself in mud, no one believes it. As a Nigerian, I’m reminded of that whenever I encounter some of the exquisite objects looted from Benin City, in southern Nigeria, in Western museums.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Crystal Martin
title: The $20 Luxury Face Cream
description: There’s a boom in low cost skin-care products with a luxury vibe. Here, a look at some of the best of the new class.
content: Remember the heyday of high-end miracle moisturizers? Creams could promise beautiful skin via proprietary elixirs and secret blends. For a long time, luxury skin care put a big price tag on mystery — ingredients that spurred hope and wonder in a pretty jar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Dominic Thiem Beats Rafael Nadal in Australian Open Quarterfinal
description: Thiem won in a thrilling four sets and will face Alexander Zverev in one semifinal. Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic are in the other.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — There will be a new-generation men’s semifinal at the Australian Open when Dominic Thiem faces Alexander Zverev for a chance to take on one of the sport’s Big Three for a title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Warren Buffett Will Sell His Newspaper Empire
description: With a deal to sell Berkshire Hathaway’s newspapers to Lee Enterprises, the billionaire is giving up on the news business.
content: Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate run by Warren E. Buffett, announced on Wednesday that it had agreed to sell its 31 newspapers for $140 million in cash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Talk of Milk Industry Merger Draws Justice Dept. Scrutiny
description: Antitrust officials have been investigating a potential merger of the struggling milk giant Dean Foods with Dairy Farmers of America, a marketing cooperative.
content: When the struggling milk giant Dean Foods filed for bankruptcy protection in November, it also announced a possible path forward — a takeover by Dairy Farmers of America, a marketing cooperative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Day 8 of Trump’s Trial: Ask Me Anything
description: Senators are allotted 16 hours to question the opposing legal teams. They’re making the least of it.
content: After fidgeting their way through six days of opening arguments in the impeachment trial of President Trump, rank-and-file senators were at last allowed to participate, as Wednesday kicked off up to 16 hours of question-and-answer time spread over two days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and David McCabe
title: Interior Dept. Grounds Its Drones Over Chinese Spying Fears
description: The order formalizes a decision last year to ground the federal agency’s drones pending an internal security investigation.
content: WASHINGTON — The Interior Department announced on Wednesday that it was grounding its entire fleet of drones out of concerns that Chinese parts in them might be used for spying, making exceptions only for emergency missions like fighting wildfires and search-and-rescue operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Legal Pads, Photographs and a Podcast: How Senators Are Documenting Impeachment
description: Senators, who serve as jurors and judges in President Trump’s impeachment trial, are also acting as tourists and historians of the rare proceeding.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Ben Sasse, Republican of Nebraska, first picked up the habit in grade school, scribbling notes in ink on 3-by-5-inch graph paper index cards as a mechanism to keep his handwriting small and his thoughts organized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Celebrating the Kansas City Chiefs, the Chop Divides
description: Chiefs fans have relished doing the tomahawk chop since the early 1990s. But to many Native Americans and others, the gesture is an offensive mockery of the nation’s first people.
content: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The night was winding down at The Rieger, an upscale casual restaurant in Kansas City, and a couple of Denver Broncos fans in town for a game last month were standing at the bar, engaging in some friendly ribbing with supporters of the hometown Chiefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Rosenthal
title: How to Avoid the Coronavirus? Wash Your Hands
description: I covered the SARS outbreak as a reporter in China, and I saw that common sense is the best defense against viral illness.
content: Americans are watching with alarm as a new coronavirus spreads in China and cases pop up in the United States. They are barraged with information about what kinds of masks are best to prevent viral spread. Students are handing out masks in Seattle. Masks have run out in Brazos County, Tex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: After All These Years, Barbie Is Still Reinventing Herself
description: Mattel continues to try to appeal to more consumers, this time by making dolls with a prosthetic limb, no hair and vitiligo.
content: One doll is bald. Another has a prosthetic limb. And another doll’s curly dark hair is swept away from her face to show she has vitiligo, a condition that causes patches of skin to lose melanin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz and Jonathan Corum
title: This Sculpture Holds a Decades-Old C.I.A. Mystery. And Now, Another Clue.
description: Kryptos has been in a courtyard at C.I.A. headquarters for almost 30 years. Three of its four passages have been decoded. Will one more clue unlock the last?
content: Kryptos has been in a courtyard at C.I.A. headquarters for almost 30 years. Three of its four passages have been decoded. Will one more clue unlock the last?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Super PAC Attacks Sanders in an Ad. Sanders Raises $1.3 Million in a Day.
description: As Bernie Sanders shows strength in the early-voting states, his opponents face a challenge: Attacking him can help fuel his campaign.
content: DES MOINES — A Democratic super PAC wanted to undermine Senator Bernie Sanders’s presidential candidacy just days before the Iowa caucuses. It may have handed him a gift instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Richarz
title: A Few Etiquette Tips for Getting Around Japan
description: Heading to Tokyo for the 2020 Summer Olympics? Here are some lesser-known tips on avoiding faux pas and other cultural missteps while there.
content: Japanese society, known for its polite orderliness, is heavily dependent on unspoken understandings and behavior aimed at maintaining the “wa” — the idea of social harmony. With Tokyo bracing for an influx of tourists for the 2020 Summer Olympics, here are some lesser-known tips for first-timers on avoiding faux pas and other cultural missteps while in Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $1 Million Homes in South Dakota, Illinois and Rhode Island
description: A riverfront showplace near Sioux City, a minimalist condo in Chicago and a 1680 farmhouse outside Providence.
content: Sitting on the shores of the Missouri River, as well as at the edge of an Arnold Palmer-designed golf course, this property is in a 2,000-acre master-planned community with about 1,250 homes, about five miles south of North Sioux City, S.D., and seven miles west of downtown Sioux City, Iowa. (Its location in the extreme southeastern corner of the state also places it near the border of Nebraska.) Interstate 29 runs nearby, with access to major east-west freeways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J.D. Maddox
title: The Day I Realized I Would Never Find Weapons of Mass Destruction in Iraq
description: As an intelligence officer assigned to the Iraq Survey Group, I stumbled into the most revealing truth of the conflict.
content: I rolled west from Baghdad in a convoy of soft-side Humvees. It was a morning in late June 2003, and I had traded a bottle of whiskey for the use of an American military police detachment as protection for a daylong mission to Abu Ghraib prison. As an intelligence officer for the Department of Energy assigned to the Iraq Survey Group — the American-led team searching for weapons of mass destruction in Iraq — I was scheduled to interview an Iraqi prisoner who had been captured weeks before, on suspicion of transporting stolen nuclear material. I couldn’t know it that morning, but the interview would entirely change my perspective on America’s involvement in Iraq, and set me on a decades-long course of struggling with the false narratives used to persuade us to march into that conflict and other ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Steiner
title: For Some Resorts, Multi-Mountain Passes Mean Crowded Slopes and Longer Lift Lines
description: The popularity of IKON and Epic passes have ski resorts cutting off weekend sales at the windows and warning crowds on social media to stay home.
content: Last month, the Crystal Mountain Resort announced it would no longer sell ski-lift tickets at its windows on weekends, a startling move in an industry that has historically sought volume and the high margin returns from single-day lift ticket sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: After All These Years, Barbie Is Still Reinventing Herself
description: Mattel continues to try to appeal to more consumers, this time by making dolls with a prosthetic limb, no hair and vitiligo.
content: One doll is bald. Another has a prosthetic limb. And another doll’s curly dark hair is swept away from her face to show she has vitiligo, a condition that causes patches of skin to lose melanin.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What to See Right Now in New York Art Galleries
description: Katherine Bernhardt’s E.T. paintings; Michael Rakowitz’s reconstructions of antiquities; and Juanita McNeely’s contorted female figures.
content: People of all ages fell for the cute gnome-like alien at the center of Steven Spielberg’s 1982 movie “E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial.” But some fell extra hard; Katherine Bernhardt, who turned 7 the year the movie premiered, was smitten enough to paint portraits of E.T. in art school. In her latest show, “Done with Xanax,” she returns to him, pushing her distinctive fusion of Pop Art, Color Field and graffiti toward a more vulnerable, narrative expression and more complex painting process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz and Jonathan Corum
title: This Sculpture Holds a Decades-Old C.I.A. Mystery. And Now, Another Clue.
description: Kryptos has been in a courtyard at C.I.A. headquarters for almost 30 years. Three of its four passages have been decoded. Will one more clue unlock the last?
content: Kryptos has been in a courtyard at C.I.A. headquarters for almost 30 years. Three of its four passages have been decoded. Will one more clue unlock the last?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and David McCabe
title: Interior Dept. Grounds Its Drones Over Chinese Spying Fears
description: The order formalizes a decision last year to ground the federal agency’s drones pending an internal security investigation.
content: WASHINGTON — The Interior Department announced on Wednesday that it was grounding its entire fleet of drones out of concerns that Chinese parts in them might be used for spying, making exceptions only for emergency missions like fighting wildfires and search-and-rescue operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aileen Jacobson
title: Sugar Hill, Manhattan: The Sweet Life of Old New York
description: The Harlem neighborhood that Langston Hughes praised in 1944 is still one of the ‘best-kept secrets in New York.’ But it’s not quite as affordable as it once was.
content: Langston Hughes, the acclaimed writer and prominent Harlem Renaissance figure, described Sugar Hill in a 1944 New Republic article as “that attractive rise of bluff,” where people are likely to live in homes “where the plumbing really works and the ceilings are high and airy. For just a few thousands a year one can live very well on Sugar Hill in a house with a white-tiled hall.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Franz Mazura, 95, Opera Singer Whose Specialty Was Villains, Dies
description: An imposing Austrian bass-baritone, his first major international appearance came in his early 40s. He continued to perform nearly until the end.
content: Franz Mazura, an Austrian bass-baritone best known for his compelling portrayals of operatic villains in a late-starting but long-lasting career that brought him to many of the world’s major houses, died on Jan. 23 in a hospital in Mannheim, Germany. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joyce Cohen
title: They Wanted a Multigenerational Home in Brooklyn. Which Apartment Did They Choose?
description: With a baby and two grandparents in the mix, a couple look for a place that can accommodate everyone. Here’s where they landed.
content: With a baby and two grandparents in the mix, a couple look for a place that can accommodate everyone. Here’s where they landed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Trump’s Digital Advantage Is Freaking Out Democratic Strategists
description: Left and right agree on one point. The president’s re-election campaign is way ahead online.
content: In a blog post published in November, a year before the 2020 election, Brian Burch, the president of CatholicVote.org, a socially conservative advocacy group, announced that in Wisconsin alone his organization had identified 199,241 Catholics “who’ve been to church at least 3 times in the last 90 days.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Tech Loses a Prophet. Just When It Needs One.
description: Clay Christensen’s bracing ideas about management are more relevant than ever as the tech industry seeks redemption.
content: It’s nothing but noise, all the time. We get hammered every second from an incessant sousaphone of tweets and from the righteous rage machine that screams at us in this digitized 24/7/365 communications world that we have built.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Rosenthal
title: How to Avoid the Coronavirus? Wash Your Hands
description: I covered the SARS outbreak as a reporter in China, and I saw that common sense is the best defense against viral illness.
content: Americans are watching with alarm as a new coronavirus spreads in China and cases pop up in the United States. They are barraged with information about what kinds of masks are best to prevent viral spread. Students are handing out masks in Seattle. Masks have run out in Brazos County, Tex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Emily Cochrane
title: Trump Signs Trade Deal With Canada and Mexico
description: President Trump signed the trade deal at the White House, fulfilling a campaign promise to rewrite the North American trade rules.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump signed the revised North American Free Trade Agreement into law on Wednesday, fulfilling a key campaign promise and bringing more than two years of tumultuous negotiations over the continent’s trade rules to a close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Sapna Maheshwari and Katherine Rosman
title: Les Wexner, Victoria’s Secret Owner, Is in Talks to Step Down
description: Mr. Wexner, who created the retail empire L Brands, has come under scrutiny for employing the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein as a personal adviser.
content: Leslie H. Wexner, the longtime leader of a retail empire that includes Victoria’s Secret who is under scrutiny for his ties to the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein, has been in discussions to step aside as chief executive of the L Brands parent company, according to one current and one former executive who spoke on condition of anonymity to talk about internal deliberations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: 14 New Books to Watch For in February
description: Fraught friendships, coming-of-age stories, Supreme Court drama and more.
content: Ever since his refugee application was denied, Danny, who came to Australia from Sri Lanka, has tried to stay under the radar. But when he hears about a murder — and realizes he may hold a key to the case — he must weigh the risks of exposing his undocumented status to the authorities. Adiga, the author of the Booker Prize-winning novel “The White Tiger,” brings to life the precarious circumstances and impossible choices that immigrants face in his new book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Austin Ramzy
title: Foreigners Airlifted From Chinese City at Heart of Coronavirus Outbreak
description: More than a dozen nations pulled their citizens from Wuhan. But how evacuees were handled once they got home varied country by country.
content: LOS ANGELES — About 200 Americans evacuated from Wuhan, China, landed at a military base in Southern California on Wednesday, as countries around the world began pulling their citizens from the epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: Mask Hoarders May Raise Risk of a Coronavirus Outbreak in the U.S.
description: Stores are selling out of masks, and health care workers risk infection if they cannot get the protective gear.
content: Even though there are only five cases of Wuhan coronavirus in the United States, the mask hoarding has begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: How Los Angeles Counts Its Homeless Population
description: Wednesday: Last week, hundreds of volunteers around California fanned out to count homeless populations. Also: The latest on Kobe Bryant’s death.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Sarah Anderson
title: Israel, Coronavirus, Huawei: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Arts Collective Founder to Lead a Children’s Museum
description: Seth Cameron of the Bruce High Quality Foundation will be the next head of the Children’s Museum of the Arts.
content: A children’s museum would seem a world away from an artists’ collective. But Seth Cameron will be making that leap when he becomes the next executive director of the Children’s Museum of the Arts in SoHo, beginning Feb 3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
title: On the Day Democrats Vote in Iowa, Trump Plans to Flood the Zone
description: Roughly 80 members of Congress, cabinet secretaries and administration officials will descend on the state to drive voter enthusiasm and make a show of force.
content: WASHINGTON — The Iowa caucuses on Monday will be a competitive race for only one party, the Democrats, but President Trump’s campaign does not see it that way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Vora
title: Where Street Art Comes Indoors and Legos Climb the Walls
description: Fun-house flair mingles with equally bold but more stately pieces at David and Isabela Grutman’s home.
content: MIAMI BEACH — To say that the art in David and Isabela Grutman’s home bombards the senses is an understatement. Over the last 15 years, Mr. Grutman, 45, a restaurateur and club owner, has amassed a sizable collection of head-turning pieces. Many are sculptures, but paintings, street art and installations in bold colors also figure in it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Declan Walsh
title: A Muted Arab Response to Trump’s Mideast Peace Plan
description: The U.S. is banking on Arab leaders to help make its plan for ending the Israeli-Palestinian conflict work. It is not clear how realistic that is.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In unveiling his plan Tuesday for solving the conflict between Israel and the Palestinians, President Trump confidently declared that Arab countries would play a key role in its success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Blacki Migliozzi
title: What Are 2020 Democrats Saying to Iowans in Facebook Ads?
description: We analyzed the messaging in Facebook ads that appeared on voters’ screens in Iowa in the days leading up to the caucuses.
content: We analyzed the messaging in Facebook ads that appeared on voters’ screens in Iowa in the days leading up to the caucuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Astead W. Herndon
title: Elizabeth Warren’s Iowa Pivot: From Her Plans to Her Plan to Win
description: In the final days before the caucuses, Ms. Warren is taking on the electability question in ads, on the stump and on her campaign bus, urging voters to embrace “courage over cynicism” and “hope over fear.”
content: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — The last time Senator Elizabeth Warren trundled across Iowa in a specially decorated campaign vehicle, an R.V. headed to the Iowa State Fair in August, it was wrapped with a cheeky play on the slogan for her sweeping agenda: “Honk if you’re ready for big, structural change!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips and Jeanna Smialek
title: As Fed Meets, Treasury Bill-Buying Campaign Draws Investors’ Eyes
description: The central bank has been swelling its balance sheet, but the pace is expected to slow. In an ebullient market, hints at how and when could hurt stock prices.
content: After months of mostly smooth sailing, is the market getting ready to throw a tantrum?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Morning Moods
description: How do you typically greet the day?
content: Do you tend to wake up on the “wrong side of the bed” or “bright-eyed and bushy-tailed”? Do mornings invite optimism and inspiration, or provoke repeated hits of the snooze button and caffeine swigging?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shirley Wang
title: How the Iowa Caucuses Work
description: A little bit of choice, a whole lot of chaos.
content: DAVENPORT, Iowa — “So if you’re with pineapple the first round, and there are enough voters, do pineapples become viable and you can no longer change to blueberries?” a man at the table near me asked.

title: The Super Bowl Is the Biggest Art Show in Miami Right Now
description: Vibrant murals, tropical-colored tickets and one giant, flamboyantly bright Lombardi Trophy: Exuberant street art takes over the big game this year.
content: The Super Bowl is back in Miami this year, and the organizers are giving a bear hug to the bold, exuberant street art that is a hallmark of the host city.

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Beware the Pandemic Panic
description: Coronavirus is scary. How we respond to it may be worse.
content: Coronavirus is starting to freak me out — not the illness itself but the amped-up, ill-considered way our frightened world might respond to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
description: The central bank suggested it would remain patient after cutting rates three times in 2019.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged at their first meeting of 2020 on Wednesday, upholding their patient stance after an active, and often tumultuous, 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Mike Isaac
title: Lyft Plans Job Cuts as Part of Restructuring
description: The ride-hailing company has faced questions about whether it can make money.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Lyft said on Wednesday that it was embarking on a corporate restructuring that would result in job cuts, as the ride-hailing company grapples with questions about whether it can make money.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump’s Mideast Plan: Good for Whom?
description: Readers variously see a gift to Israel and a missed opportunity for Palestinians. Also: The anniversary of Auschwitz’s liberation; gay men and crystal meth addiction.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: The Last Ads in Iowa
description: It’s time for the candidates’ final TV pitches to caucusgoers — and these ads can tell us a lot.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti, your host on Tuesdays for our coverage of all things media and messaging.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 29, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 29, 2020.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the death of Kobe Bryant misspelled the surname of the chief medical examiner for Los Angeles County. He is Jonathan Lucas, not Luca.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Louise Kelly
title: Pompeo Called Me a ‘Liar.’ That’s Not What Bothers Me.
description: Journalists are supposed to ask tough questions, then share the answers — or lack thereof — with the world.
content: Ask journalists why they do the job they do, and you’ll hear a range of answers. Here’s mine: Not every day, but on the best ones, we get to put questions to powerful people and hold them to account. This is both a privilege and a responsibility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Test Your Super Bowl Knowledge
description: Test your N.F.L. knowledge before the Kansas City Chiefs face the San Francisco 49ers for Super Bowl LIV.

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Brexit Is Finally Happening, but the Complicated Part Is Just Beginning
description: When Britain officially leaves the E.U. on Jan. 31, it will open a potentially more volatile chapter in this drawn-out saga, as negotiators try to reach a trade deal.
content: GLASGOW — As a man who makes whisky for a living, Antony McCallum knows how to wait patiently for the years to pass. He buys spirits from across Scotland, entrusts the liquid to wooden barrels stashed in dark warehouses, and then allows time to perform its alchemy.

author: By Mujib Mashal and Najim Rahim
title: Despite Calm in Afghan Cities, War in Villages Kills Dozens Daily
description: A reduction in attacks in major Afghan cities amid American peace talks with the Taliban could be misleading. Bloodletting in the countryside continues.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Over the past couple of months, as American and Taliban negotiators have resumed talks to try to complete a peace deal, an unusual calm has settled over major Afghan cities. Deadly terrorism attacks, once frequent, have suddenly dropped in urban centers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Super Bowl Is the Biggest Art Show in Miami Right Now

author: By Dan Brooks
title: Comedy Written for the Machines
description: A viral TikTok video hints at what culture could look like under the sway of mysterious, A.I.-powered algorithms.
content: I am going to describe a video that threw me into a pit of despair. It begins with a woman running into the aisle of a big-box store and telling a tween boy that she needs phone chargers. He asks why; she says all her chargers are missing. “You came to the right place,” he says, gesturing to the rack next to him. “This is Android, though,” the woman says. “I need iPhone.” The boy tells her she will find iPhone chargers if she takes five steps back. Here the performance shifts from mere stiltedness to a kind of hateful Kabuki, an affected defiance of how people naturally act: She walks backward, counting her steps, then turns and slaps her forehead. “Whoa,” she says. “That was so . . . amazing.” She drops a charger trying to take it off the rack. “Whoops,” she says, looking at the camera without affect. The boy says, “Androids are trash, but they make a living” — a phrase that comes to me now unbidden as I fall asleep, jolting me awake in a way I imagine is common to unpunished murderers. The woman says that iPhones make a living, too, and asks, “You ready to cash out?” Then it’s over.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Temperatures at a Florida-Size Glacier in Antarctica Alarm Scientists
description: Researchers in Antarctica found unusually warm water beneath a massive glacier that is already melting and contributing to sea level rise.
content: Scientists in Antarctica have recorded, for the first time, unusually warm water beneath a glacier the size of Florida that is already melting and contributing to a rise in sea levels.

title: ‘There Aren’t Enough Words to Describe Our Pain,’ Kobe Bryant’s Wife Says
description: Vanessa Bryant spoke out for the first time while Los Angeles stands ready to accommodate thousands of mourners.
content: Vanessa Bryant, the widow of Kobe Bryant, posted a statement to her Instagram on Wednesday evening paying tribute to her husband and daughter Gianna, who both died in a helicopter crash on Sunday that killed seven others. In the post, Bryant thanked those who had expressed their condolences following the tragedy.

title: Coronavirus in New York: Lunar New Year Events Canceled Over Fears
description: No confirmed case of the virus has been found in the state. But anxiety is growing in New York City’s Chinese community.
content: The Lunar New Year Chinese Temple Bazaar in Queens typically attracts hundreds of spectators who come to watch an array of dancers and artists.

title: ‘There’s No Playbook’: Recalling the Pain of Lost Teammates
description: Kobe Bryant’s death brought back difficult memories for those close to Thurman Munson and Roberto Clemente, two other athletes who died in accidents near the peak of their fame.
content: LOS ANGELES — For Jim Kaat, the hours after his teammate’s death were filled with questions that had no answers.

author: By Katie Rogers
title: At Rally, Trump Praises Van Drew for Leaving ‘Deranged’ Democratic Party
description: The president traveled to Wildwood, N.J., to return a political favor for a former moderate Democrat who last month switched parties and pledged his “undying support.”
content: WILDWOOD, N.J. — President Trump told his supporters at a raucous rally on Tuesday evening that Representative Jeff Van Drew of New Jersey, who recently left the Democratic Party, was a symbol of the future. Without evidence, he said that an increasing number of Americans were “disgusted” by congressional Democrats who, he said, are “obsessed with demented hoaxes, this crazy witch hunt and deranged partisan crusades.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mohamad Bazzi
title: The New Lebanon Is the Old Lebanon
description: The country needs structural economic and political reform. That can’t happen unless the ruling elite reforms itself out of power.
content: On Jan. 21, Lebanese leaders agreed to form a new government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert P. George
title: Roger Scruton Was a Conservative. But What Kind?
description: The philosopher, who died this month, defied stereotypes by remaining true to his moral sensibility.
content: Sir Roger Scruton, who died this month at age 75, was a longstanding and dear friend of mine. Although we represented different philosophical schools — Roger leaning in a Kantian direction, I being a dyed-in-the-wool Aristotelian — our interests and ultimate conclusions often overlapped. I learned an enormous amount from reading his work and even more from our conversations.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Corporations are bracing for the repercussions of the outbreak, with major retailers closing stores and airlines cutting flights to and from the country.

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Kenji, Alison and Jamie, Oh My!
description: Moo shu mushrooms, caramelized shallot pasta, and black bean burgers: Cook these new recipes from some of the greats.
content: Good morning. Our J. Kenji López-Alt gave us a fantastic new recipe this week for moo shu mushrooms (above), based on the pork version his parents were introduced to by the chef Joyce Chen, who died in 1994. It’s accompanied by instructions on how to make Mandarin pancakes for wrapping the moo shu, but no one’s going to object on a Wednesday if you don’t do that. As Kenji advises, you can always serve the dish as the strip-mall Chinese restaurants do, with warm flour tortillas. Either way, you’ll eat very well.
source.name: The New York Times

content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxana Popescu
title: House Hunting in Amsterdam: A Restored Triplex for $1.9 Million
description: With an expanding expatriate population and lagging development, the Dutch capital is raising its profile as a European hub, with the prices to match.
content: This six-bedroom, two-bathroom townhouse triplex is in the leafy, upscale Weesperzijde residential neighborhood of Amsterdam, on the eastern bank of the Amstel river, near the heart of the city. The home includes the bottom three levels of a five-level house: a basement level, garden level and first floor. The two floors above contain apartments with separate entrances and are not included in the sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer and Mike Isaac
title: Facebook to Pay $550 Million to Settle Facial Recognition Suit
description: It was another black mark on the privacy record of the social network, which also reported its quarterly earnings.
content: Facebook said on Wednesday that it had agreed to pay $550 million to settle a class-action lawsuit over its use of facial recognition technology in Illinois, giving privacy groups a major victory that again raised questions about the social network’s data-mining practices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: ‘There’s No Playbook’: Recalling the Pain of Lost Teammates
description: Kobe Bryant’s death brought back difficult memories for those close to Thurman Munson and Roberto Clemente, two other athletes who died in accidents near the peak of their fame.
content: LOS ANGELES — For Jim Kaat, the hours after his teammate’s death were filled with questions that had no answers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Living In ... Sugar Hill, Manhattan
description: The Harlem neighborhood that Langston Hughes praised in 1944 is still ‘one of the best-kept secrets in New York,’ although it’s not quite as affordable as it once was.
content: The Harlem neighborhood that Langston Hughes praised in 1944 is still ‘one of the best-kept secrets in New York,’ although it’s not quite as affordable as it once was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Kenji, Alison and Jamie, Oh My!
description: Moo shu mushrooms, caramelized shallot pasta, and black bean burgers: Cook these new recipes from some of the greats.
content: Good morning. Our J. Kenji López-Alt gave us a fantastic new recipe this week for moo shu mushrooms (above), based on the pork version his parents were introduced to by the chef Joyce Chen, who died in 1994. It’s accompanied by instructions on how to make Mandarin pancakes for wrapping the moo shu, but no one’s going to object on a Wednesday if you don’t do that. As Kenji advises, you can always serve the dish as the strip-mall Chinese restaurants do, with warm flour tortillas. Either way, you’ll eat very well.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How the Coronavirus Could Hurt Apple and Starbucks
description: Corporations are bracing for the repercussions of the outbreak, with major retailers closing stores and airlines cutting flights to and from the country.
content: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: At Rally, Trump Praises Van Drew for Leaving ‘Deranged’ Democratic Party
description: The president traveled to Wildwood, N.J., to return a political favor for a former moderate Democrat who last month switched parties and pledged his “undying support.”
content: WILDWOOD, N.J. — President Trump told his supporters at a raucous rally on Tuesday evening that Representative Jeff Van Drew of New Jersey, who recently left the Democratic Party, was a symbol of the future. Without evidence, he said that an increasing number of Americans were “disgusted” by congressional Democrats who, he said, are “obsessed with demented hoaxes, this crazy witch hunt and deranged partisan crusades.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Dusty Baker Hired as Astros’ Manager in Wake of Scandal
description: Baker, one of the most experienced managers in baseball, is Houston’s choice to help guide the club after an illegal sign-stealing scheme tarnished the team’s reputation.
content: Hoping to move past one of the biggest scandals in baseball history, the Houston Astros are turning to one of the most accomplished managers on the market: Dusty Baker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘The Curse of La Llorona’ and ‘Night on Earth’
description: A horror blockbuster is available to stream on HBO platforms. And a new Netflix nature series captures the outdoors at night.
content: THE CURSE OF LA LLORONA (2019) Stream on HBO platforms. The threat is veiled (in the literal sense) in “The Curse of La Llorona,” a horror movie about a killer spirit who takes the form of a weeping woman in a wedding dress. The movie casts Linda Cardellini as Anna, a widow with two children, a job in social services and a problem audiences can probably extrapolate from the film’s title: She’s cursed. Or, rather, she picks up a curse that comes in the form of La Llorona (Marisol Ramirez), a weeping woman who starts terrorizing the family. (The character is based on a figure from Mexican folklore.) “More efficient than ambitious, ‘La Llorona’ is basically a maternal showdown with shock cuts and billowing curtains,” Manohla Dargis wrote in her review for The New York Times. “The director Michael Chaves, making the most of his silkily mobile, at times predatory camera (he likes to shift the point of view mid-prowl) delivers the horror classics nicely.” One of the movie’s producers is James Wan, known for the “Saw” and “Conjuring” movies. Fans of either of those series should be well served here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: A Texas-Size Defeat for the E.U.: Brexit Is Here
description: The loss of such a rich, sizable, powerful member state will weaken the European Union’s momentum and its diplomatic weight.
content: The European Parliament voted in Brussels on Wednesday to ratify the withdrawal agreement that governs Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union, which will formally happen on Friday at midnight Brussels time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Oscar’s Most Talented Newcomer Is 59-Year-Old Antonio Banderas
description: A first-time nominee for “Pain and Glory,” the actor talks frankly about how his recent heart attack rescued him from a career that was going in circles.
content: Your Carpetbagger rarely plays favorites while covering the Oscar race, but when it comes to this year’s best-actor contender Antonio Banderas … well, who wouldn’t love to see his well-deserved comeback come to a glittery conclusion?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘The Good Place’ and ‘BoJack Horseman’ Took Us to Hell and Back
description: TV’s two great moral comedies, both ending this week, showed us that doing the right thing in a fallen world is a group effort.
content: In the penultimate episode of “The Good Place,” after four seasons wandering the afterlife, our dear-departed heroes finally make it to the destination promised in the title. It is, of course, beautiful, with lush gardens and buildings with alabaster walls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: She Was Prescribed Three Antibiotics but Only Got Worse. Why?
description: After traveling abroad, the college student had a cough, headache and congestion that wouldn’t go away.
content: The young woman suddenly stopped in the middle of the sidewalk in New Haven, Conn.; her backpack felt strangely heavy. The weight on her shoulders seemed unbearable, as if the bag were filled with bricks rather than the usual notebooks, pens, computer and water bottle. She swung the bag to the ground as the flow of pedestrian traffic streamed around her. Her shoulders throbbed, and her back felt sore. Her legs trembled from the effort of walking. Still, she couldn’t just stand there on the street. She was in her last semester of college, and she had to get to a lecture. She heaved her backpack onto her shoulders and slowly made her way across campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Central Michigan’s Left Tackle Factory (Some Assembly Required)
description: San Francisco’s Joe Staley was a track star and a tight end. Kansas City’s Eric Fisher was as skinny as a wide receiver. A small program built them into blind-side monsters.
content: MIAMI — Turning to his left and looking to make a play, Nick Mullens tried to flip a screen pass in a meaningless December game between the San Francisco 49ers and the Denver Broncos in 2018, only to have Shelby Harris, a defensive tackle for the Broncos, knock the pass off its trajectory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Keeping Aging Muscles Fit Is Tied to Better Heart Health Later
description: For men at least, entering middle age with plenty of muscle may lower the later risk of developing heart disease by more than 80 percent.
content: How much muscle you have now could indicate how healthy your heart will be later, according to an interesting new study of muscle mass and cardiovascular disease. The study finds that, for men at least, entering middle age with plenty of muscle lowers the subsequent risk of developing heart disease by as much as 81 percent, compared to the risks for other men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah A. Topol
title: Her Uighur Parents Were Model Chinese Citizens. It Didn’t Matter.
description: When Zulhumar Isaac’s parents disappeared amid a wave of detentions of ethnic minorities, she had to play a perilous game with the state to get them back.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Modern Love Podcast: Tan France Reads ‘A Role I Was Born to Play’
description: The “Queer Eye” star and “Next in Fashion” host reads an essay about choosing not to have children.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynn Vavreck and Chris Tausanovitch
title: Are Democratic Voters Truly Divided by Ideology?
description: Survey results suggests their views and priorities are far more alike than different, despite labels like moderate or progressive, centrist or liberal.
content: The four Democratic candidates at the top of the polls heading into the Iowa caucuses have been paired by pundits into what they like to call lanes. It’s a highway analogy, as in “stay in your lane.” One, seen as more progressive and liberal, contains Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren. The other, consisting of Joe Biden and Pete Buttigieg, is more centrist and moderate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Behind the Racial Uproar at One of the World’s Best Jazz Stations
description: WBGO seems to be distancing itself from the community that built it. There have been repercussions.
content: For almost 40 years, Dorthaan Kirk, the widow of the great jazz saxophonist Rahsaan Roland Kirk, was a fixture at WBGO, Newark’s public jazz station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Fretts
title: ‘1917’ and the Challenge of Making a Film Look Like a Single Shot
description: The cinematographer Roger Deakins didn’t know the plan was to make it look like a real-time story until he received the script: “That was a bit of a shock.”
content: Roger Deakins received his first Oscar nomination for best cinematography 25 years ago, for “The Shawshank Redemption.” He would earn 13 more before he finally won in 2018 for “Blade Runner 2049.” This year, he’s in the running again for his bravura work on the World War I drama “1917.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Warzel
title: What Will You Do When the Culture War Comes for You?
description: Newsrooms still aren’t ready for the trolls.
content: The culture war will come for us all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Micaéla Birmingham
title: My Phoneless 11-Year-Old Was Lost in Manhattan and Survived
description: I’m sticking to my principles on not getting smartphones for my tweens — even though my child got lost on the dark streets of New York City.
content: My kids are awesome and I’m doing what I can to keep them that way. Even though nearly every kid in sixth grade has a smartphone, my husband and I have chosen to delay getting them for our daughters, who are 10 and 11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: Weinstein Accuser Says He Told Her, ‘This Is How the Industry Works’
description: Dawn Dunning, one of two women who testified against Harvey Weinstein, said he sexually assaulted her in the early 2000s.
content: The women were young aspiring actresses waiting tables in New York in the mid 2000s when they met the producer Harvey Weinstein.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León and Alexandra Alter
title: ‘American Dirt’ Publisher Cancels Book Tour
description: Flatiron cited “specific threats to booksellers and the author” for its decision.
content: Flatiron Books, the publisher of “American Dirt,” said Wednesday that it was canceling the author’s book tour because of safety concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devi Lockwood
title: How Much of Harvard’s $40 Billion Endowment Is Invested in Fossil Fuels?
description: It’s not all that important. Any amount is too much.
content: In my senior year at Harvard, I was invited to a dinner in honor of the writer Margaret Atwood, the recipient of the 2014 Harvard Arts Medal. On my way out the door I lingered, shrugged on my coat, took a deep breath and walked up to the university’s president at the time, Drew Gilpin Faust. We had met twice: once during her office hours and at an ice cream social.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Kobe Bryant’s Many Moves to the Net
description: A complex figure both off court and on, the basketball star brought as much cerebral intensity to image creation as he did to his game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: More Than 7,700 Cases of Coronavirus Recorded Worldwide
description: Chinese officials have confirmed over 7,700 cases of the mysterious illness as foreign governments airlifted their citizens out of Wuhan, the outbreak’s epicenter.
content: Mainland China now has more cases of coronavirus than it had of SARS, a respiratory infection that spread across China in 2002 and 2003 and killed 774 people in 17 countries.  During the SARS outbreak, China had 5,327 cases and 349 deaths, according to the World Health Organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Name That Rash!
description: What a magical, germ-strewn adventure we are all on.
content: When my older girl was 18 months old, she became grouchy and listless and had a low-grade fever. A day or two later, she broke out in a bright red rash that inflamed her cheeks. “Fifth disease,” her pediatrician said, milliseconds after she walked into the exam room. I had never heard of it, and at first I thought she said “fist disease,” and I pictured a giant fist kneading my baby’s face, leaving that mass of red.
source.name: The New York Times
